<i>MGI Research</i></span><h6 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-6"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/securing-europes-competitiveness-addressing-its-technology-gap" class="mdc-c-link-heading___Zggl8_990311c mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c"><div>Securing Europe’s competitiveness: Addressing its technology gap</div></a></h6></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></main><div class="mck-u-sr-only" role="log" aria-live="polite" aria-relevant="additions" aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Investment Taking the pulse of European competitiveness","displayName":"Investment Taking the pulse of European competitiveness","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"8225d0c8-0441-4d8f-af9f-ece35ccb109e","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Investment: Taking the pulse of European competitiveness"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"European capital investment and competitiveness"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Investment is the simplest way to gauge Europe\u0026rsquo;s competitiveness\u0026mdash;and the region\u0026rsquo;s investment pulse is low."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Investment is the lifeblood of competitiveness and productivity. We look at why investment in capital is the simplest way to gauge Europe’s competitiveness."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-06-20T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]] [[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003ch2\u003eAt a glance\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eInvestment is the lifeblood of competitiveness and productivity.\u003c/strong\u003e Investment in capital, like infrastructure and machinery, accounts for 70 to 80 percent of productivity growth across regions. Much of the rest comes from investing in R\u0026amp;D, human capital, and other intangible assets. Insufficient investment compromises Europe\u0026rsquo;s competitiveness, way of life, and place in the world\u0026mdash;and without competitiveness, investment will not flow.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEurope\u0026rsquo;s investment pulse is low.\u003c/strong\u003e US investment in intellectual property (IP) and equipment is double that of Europe per capita. In 2022, large US corporations devoted about \u0026euro;700 billion more to capital expenditure and R\u0026amp;D than European peers. And Europe\u0026rsquo;s venture capital assets under management are equivalent to one-quarter of the US total.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEurope needs to reemphasize removing well-known barriers to investment to raise its pulse.\u003c/strong\u003e Barriers include energy costs, talent shortages, business and labor market regulation, and geo- and macroeconomic uncertainty.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eInvestment is the best pulse check to guide action on reducing barriers and boosting competitiveness.\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;It is simpler than competitiveness rankings, is more forward-looking than productivity, and signals commitment. For every action, the question should be, \u0026ldquo;Does it raise or lower investment?\u0026rdquo; For example, would bridging today\u0026rsquo;s four-percentage-point gap with the United States on returns on invested capital hinder or unlock more investment? Would a change in public accounting standards help raise net public investment above the current 1 percent of total public expenditure? Would industrial policy retain capital-intensive industries and help scale up capital-hungry technologies?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eInvestment in capital expenditure and innovation is the lifeblood of competitiveness\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEconomists typically define competitiveness as productivity,\u003c/strong\u003e which results from a wide range of factors, including infrastructure, labor, fiscal and monetary policies, finance, and, more broadly, institutions. Competitiveness is not easy to measure and does not always resonate with businesses that ultimately benefit from and drive it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA simpler way to take the pulse of competitiveness is to measure investment. Why? First, investment matters. From 1997 to 2022, 70 to 80 percent of productivity growth was the result of capital deepening\u0026mdash;investment in infrastructure, property, plants, machinery, equipment, and so on.[[Footnote 1]] The rest came from total factor productivity that often relates to innovation, which, in turn, links with investment in R\u0026amp;D, human capital, and other intangible assets. Half of the slowdown in productivity growth in Europe and the United States since the mid-2000s can be traced to a persistent decline in the growth of capital per worker.[[Footnote 2]] Second, investment is more forward-looking than many other economic indicators, such as productivity and GDP, and represents a commitment to a region. Third, it is strikingly simple and can therefore help stakeholders negotiate their way through complexity and trade-offs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA region that is not investing cannot be competitive, and a region that is not competitive will fail to attract domestic or foreign investment: a vicious circle. For Europe, defined here as the 27 member states of the European Union (EU) plus Norway, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom (also referred to as Europe 30), failing to increase investment puts Europe\u0026rsquo;s prosperity, way of life, and place in the world at risk.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eEurope\u0026rsquo;s investment pulse is low\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEurope\u0026rsquo;s net investment in the most productive assets is low both in comparison with the level before the global financial crisis and in comparison with that of the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAfter the global financial crisis, net investment fell precipitously, and it remains down \u0026euro;550 billion a year \u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter the global financial crisis, net investment in the United States and Europe fell significantly, but the decline was especially pronounced in Europe amid the Eurozone crisis, an environment of austerity, and weak demand (Exhibit 1). In the past decade, European net investment rates as a share of GDP were on average 2.8 percentage points or about \u0026euro;550 billion a year (nominal) lower than in the decade before the global financial crisis. Note that this research emphasizes net fixed capital formation (that is, after subtracting depreciation and impairment of existing assets) rather than the more commonly used gross numbers. This is because only net additions to the capital stock, not their replacement, drive capital deepening, productivity, and wealth.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003ch3\u003eOther regions are outpacing Europe in attracting investment\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOver the past 25 years, capital per worker has grown by 10 percent in real terms in Western Europe, by 50 percent in North America, and by 700 percent in China (Exhibit 2).[[Footnote 3]] Western Europe is the only region whose total factor productivity has fallen over the past quarter century.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003ch3\u003eThe United States invests more than twice as much per capita in the most productive assets\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile Europe\u0026rsquo;s investment share of GDP appears to be healthy on the surface, Europe is not investing on the same order of magnitude as the United States in what are typically the most productive types of investments, namely machinery and equipment, IP, and intangibles. Intangibles, including R\u0026amp;D and software in particular, play an increasingly important role in today\u0026rsquo;s economies. They generate economic returns of about 25 percent\u0026mdash;that is, an increase in annual GDP of 25 cents on each dollar invested\u0026mdash;more than other assets.[[Footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe United States is investing two percentage points of GDP more than Europe in IP and machinery. Leaving aside differences in per capita GDP, this is twice as much (\u0026euro;4,900 per year) in per capita terms (Exhibit 3). It is notable that Europe\u0026rsquo;s share of gross domestic expenditure on R\u0026amp;D relative to the United States and China fell from 39 percent in 2010 to 29 percent in 2021. Moreover, Europe\u0026rsquo;s spending has tended to be directed toward midtech sectors much more than high-tech ones.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eEurope surpasses both the United States and China in the production of scientific and journal articles.[[Footnote 5]] But its commercial innovation falls short. Europe accounts for only about 5 percent of global patent filings, compared with 15 percent for the United States and 80 percent for China.[[Footnote 6]] Competitive funding and institutional autonomy could increase the output of patents by European universities.[[Footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese important investment gaps risk going unnoticed because Europe has a slightly higher aggregate gross fixed capital formation share of GDP than the United States, but most of that stems from dwellings and other construction. It is vital to look at metrics that point to the most productive investment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eApart from Switzerland, all regions in Europe have lower investment than the United States in these two most productive types of assets. But there are differences among those regions. Holding up best are Switzerland and, to a lesser extent, Benelux, France, and the Nordic economies. Southern Europe has the most pronounced gap at 2.9 percentage points, which reflects both a decline in such investment after the global financial crisis and the fact that these economies lag behind on R\u0026amp;D and innovative sectors. The next-largest gap, at 2.7 percentage points lower than the United States, is the United Kingdom and Ireland. This reflects long-run investment weakness in the United Kingdom. Germany has the third-largest gap as well as a significant deficit in infrastructure investment. Central and Eastern Europe\u0026rsquo;s investment in these two types of assets is higher than the European average, reflecting rapid catch-up, but the region\u0026rsquo;s investment share of GDP is still lower than might be expected at its growth rates and has fallen in recent years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eLarge European firms invest \u0026euro;700 billion or about \u0026euro;3,000 per capita less than their US counterparts\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThrough a corporate rather than geographic lens, large US corporations (defined as having more than $1 billion in revenue) devoted about \u0026euro;700 billion or \u0026euro;3,000 per capita more to capital expenditure and R\u0026amp;D than their European counterparts in 2022. US corporations increased their share of total investment by large European and US firms (capital expenditure and R\u0026amp;D) from 54 percent in 2010 to 64 percent in 2022 (Exhibit 4).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe gap is evident in every sector except the materials and automotive sectors but is particularly pronounced in technology, energy, and industrials, including semiconductors (Exhibit 5). Even in industrials, which is typically a European stronghold, US firms have higher capital expenditure. Construction spending for manufacturing in the United States has doubled since the Inflation Reduction Act and CHIPS Act became law in 2022.[[Footnote 8]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eLarge US technology firms play a standout role in this difference in investment levels. Just ten US companies account for 19 percent of total investment by larger firms across the United States and Europe (Exhibit 6). The technology giants sometimes dubbed the \u0026ldquo;magnificent seven\u0026rdquo;\u0026mdash;Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta, Microsoft, Nvidia, and Tesla\u0026mdash;devoted about \u0026euro;360 billion to capital expenditure and R\u0026amp;D in 2023.[[Footnote 9]] Of course, Europe also receives some of that investment\u0026mdash;and European firms also invest abroad.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEurope has a higher share of small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) that are not part of this analysis of large firms, and SMEs tend to have lower productivity and invest less in R\u0026amp;D.[[Footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 6]]\n\u003ch3\u003eOn the funding side, Europe has scope to radically increase the supply of risk capital\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRisk capital, such as venture capital (VC) and private equity (PE), can be a particularly strong signal of investment trends, especially in the technology arena. This is where Europe lags behind the most.[[Footnote 11]] In Europe, VC assets under management as a percentage of GDP are only about one-quarter of those in the United States. PE assets under management are half the level in the United States (Exhibit 7).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 7]]\n\u003cp\u003eWithin Europe, there is large variation. Private capital raised in Sweden and the United Kingdom is 20 times higher as a share of GDP than in Germany, for instance.[[Footnote 12]] This can matter. One study found that private-capital-backed portfolio companies in Sweden on average achieved a 22 percent increase in productivity during a seven-year holding period.[[Footnote 13]] Also, 60 percent of companies in the Swedish top 200 by revenue in the past two decades were backed by private capital.[[Footnote 14]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere is an opportunity for Europe to unlock the full potential of VC and PE. Europe could also encourage higher PE and VC allocations by pension funds and insurers. This would require consolidation of these funds and changes in regulations so that they can shift fund allocations and build the required capabilities.[[Footnote 15]] Europe can take specific actions, such as creating a stable regulatory and tax environment for private investment, actively stimulating investment through government-backed programs, and supporting industry consolidation.[[Footnote 16]] As has been widely discussed, a capital markets union in the EU could further improve financial conditions.[[Footnote 17]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eEurope needs to reemphasize removing well-known barriers to raise its investment pulse \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEurope continues to face a range of barriers to investment that are well known and much discussed, but progress in bringing them down has faltered. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn one survey, European executives highlighted five main barriers to investment: high energy costs, a scarcity of people with the right skills, uncertainty about the future, regulation of businesses, and regulation of labor markets.[[Footnote 18]] The most important barriers cited in comparison with the United States were energy costs and uncertainty, which executives say are higher obstacles in Europe than in the United States. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eHigher energy costs.\u003c/em\u003e Europe remains highly dependent on energy imports. In 2022, Europe imported 63 percent of the energy it needed. By contrast, the United States has been a net exporter of energy since 2019.[[Footnote 19]]  Moreover, Europe obtains its energy from a limited number of suppliers; one-quarter of its imports came from fewer than three countries in 2021.[[Footnote 20]]  This combination of dependency on imports and the concentration of those imports proved challenging to the region\u0026rsquo;s energy-intensive industries when gas supplies were compromised in the wake of Russia\u0026rsquo;s invasion of Ukraine. For years, those supplies had helped ensure access to affordable energy for those industries. Industrial power and gas prices doubled between the first half of 2020 and the second half of 2022.[[Footnote 21]] The gap in the price of industrial electricity between Europe and the United States has been narrowing in 2024, but European prices are still significantly higher. This is a particular challenge for investment by energy-intensive firms operating, for instance, in the chemicals sector.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTalent.\u003c/em\u003e Organizations in Europe are facing a severe shortage of key talent. In a McKinsey survey, 90 percent of respondents said their companies would face a meaningful skills gap in the coming years.[[Footnote 22]] At the same time, digitization and the automation of work are leading to further skill shifts, with about 40 percent of Americans and 34 percent of Western Europeans potentially needing to switch occupational groups by 2030.[[Footnote 23]]  Moreover, 46 percent of workers globally are considering leaving their jobs in 2024, and this attrition is making it harder to retain skills within organizations.[[Footnote 24]]  While talent is not necessarily less available in Europe than in the United States, Europe will face a stronger drag from aging. Its old-age dependency ratio is expected to increase from about 35 percent in 2020 to some 50 percent in 2030.[[Footnote 25]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eUncertainty about the future.\u003c/em\u003e Uncertainty has increased, not least since Russia\u0026rsquo;s invasion of Ukraine exposed Europe\u0026rsquo;s energy dependency and geopolitical fault lines. According to European Investment Bank simulations, if uncertainty in 2022 had remained at 2021 levels, corporate investments in 2022 would have been 10 percent higher (all else being equal).[[Footnote 26]] There is also a history of Europe taking less bold action to counter macroeconomic shocks, for instance when economies fell away from the recovery following the global financial crisis into the Eurozone crisis.[[Footnote 27]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBusiness regulation.\u003c/em\u003e Business regulation was cited as a major obstacle by 25 percent of respondents in the latest European Investment Bank investment report. Moving closer to a true European single market with at least common, if not business-friendlier, rules appears to be a priority for executives. In a 2021 survey, members of the European Round Table for Industry judged that the single market was only about 75 percent complete.[[Footnote 28]]  Trade frictions within the EU have been estimated to reduce EU GDP by 5 to 10 percent.[[Footnote 29]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLabor-market regulation.\u003c/em\u003e Europe generally has less flexible labor markets than the United States. For instance, in Europe, average redundancy costs equal 15 weeks of salary, compared with zero weeks in the United States.[[Footnote 30]] It is also easier to transition between jobs in the United States, where 4 percent of the working-age population switches jobs in a quarter, compared with 3 percent in Europe.[[Footnote 31]] While labor-market flexibility is no panacea and can also entail lower investment in employee skills, it does continue to come up high as an investment barrier in executive surveys.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWays to tackle such issues have been identified, including completing the single market and ensuring that regulation is predictable.[[Footnote 32]]  Such actions have been discussed in previous MGI research and by numerous other organizations and are not detailed in this article. Our argument here\u0026mdash;in light of limited progress toward addressing these hurdles\u0026mdash;is that investment should be front and center and that so long as there is a gap, bolder action is needed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003ePrioritizing investment as a simple pulse check for important decisions could unlock action \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMaintaining Europe\u0026rsquo;s prosperity and the welfare of citizens depends on productivity and competitiveness, which, in turn, hinge on investment, not least in innovation. It is striking that if the five largest European countries had kept pace with US productivity growth from 1997 to 2022, their per capita GDP today would be $13,000 higher in purchasing power parity (PPP) terms.[[Footnote 33]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRecognizing that investment is the lifeblood of competitiveness can help Europe reprioritize, identify simpler answers to complex topics, and not only survive but thrive. Taking the pulse of investment is a simple way to measure the problem and, on that basis, act boldly and deliver. With this lens, what questions might Europe\u0026rsquo;s leaders answer differently?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCan investment flow while returns on invested capital are comparatively low?\u003c/em\u003e Treating investment as a priority also means welcoming significant returns on that investment. Yet returns on invested capital (ROIC) in corporate Europe were four percentage points lower than those in the United States between 2015 and 2022. Over that period, large public companies in Europe had an ROIC of about 14 percent, compared with about 18 percent in the United States.[[Footnote 34]] Europe\u0026rsquo;s lower returns undermine investment at a time when capital is becoming scarcer. The disparity is largest in the technology hardware, software services, and pharmaceutical sectors.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eCan Europe afford to lose its capital-intensive industries while not scaling a capital-hungry technology sector?\u003c/em\u003e Technology is growing and needs investment, and a high-labor-cost region with mounting energy costs must compete on both technology and capital. Europe is in danger of coming third in frontier technologies behind the United States and China; of ten technologies that matter for the future, Europe is leading in only two.[[Footnote 35]] Forging a more solid position in technology is becoming increasingly important as Europe\u0026rsquo;s model of industrial excellence comes under pressure from high energy costs, tight labor markets, a shift in value creation to high-technology arenas, and mounting competition, particularly from China. Without more sustained and larger-scale investment in technology, Europe could fall further behind. \u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eEurope does not need to mimic technology hyper-scalers in the United States but rather needs to build on its own strengths. Examples could range from investing in more basic research to enhancing university-industry collaboration to developing and deploying artificial intelligence in healthcare and cleantech. Public precommercial innovation procurement in key areas such as healthcare, defense, and energy\u0026mdash;at sufficient scale\u0026mdash;could unlock innovation and help create new firms. The seven leading US tech giants spent about $200 billion on R\u0026amp;D in 2023. This could be a useful yardstick to gauge the scale needed. Enabling companies to scale is vital. Ways to do so could include a \u0026ldquo;28th regime\u0026rdquo; of common business rules, cross-border consolidation, and completing the single market.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIs an allocation of 1 percent of public expenditure to net new investment the right prioritization?\u003c/em\u003e Europe\u0026rsquo;s net public investment (after depreciation of existing infrastructure) has been near zero for decades. It should be noted that net public investment in Europe is only one-100th of total public expenditure (Exhibit 8). Reallocation or efficiency of just, say, 5 percent in other public spending could raise it fivefold. Between 1995 and 2022, public-sector net fixed capital formation averaged about 0.6 percent of GDP.[[Footnote 36]]  That is only about half what the United States\u0026mdash;whose inadequate infrastructure is intensely discussed\u0026mdash;spent over this period (1.3 percent).[[Footnote 37]] At times of fiscal constraint, public investment is all too often the discretionary item that is cut, despite the fact that, if deployed effectively, it can boost demand, confidence, productivity, and therefore further investment.[[Footnote 38]] One way to safeguard public investment would be a change in public accounting standards and fiscal rules. Like corporations, governments could activate investments (with proper impairment tests to avoid white elephants) on a balance sheet so that the expenses hit budgets only as the asset depreciates over its lifetime.[[Footnote 39]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIs Europe\u0026rsquo;s macroeconomic and fiscal environment conducive to investment?\u003c/em\u003e From a corporate perspective, the clearest signals to invest are strong demand and a tight labor market. Yet a weak macroeconomy has deterred investment in Europe. When macroeconomic conditions are stable, productivity in Europe and the United States tend to move in tandem. But after every crisis in recent decades, from the bursting of the dot-com bubble to the global financial crisis to the COVID-19 pandemic, productivity failed to recover as well in Europe as it did in the United States. In the two years after each of those crises, Europe\u0026rsquo;s productivity fell relative to that of the United States by between 2 and 6 percent.[[Footnote 40]] This record argues strongly for bolder action to ensure a more stable macroeconomy. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[Exhibit 8]]\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs Europe\u0026rsquo;s decision makers tackle pressure on Europe\u0026rsquo;s competitiveness, investment needs to be center stage and one simple question asked: \u0026ldquo;Does the current environment or proposed action unlock significant investment?\u0026rdquo; Time is running out to revive Europe\u0026rsquo;s investment pulse.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":{"name":"MGI Research","displayName":"MGI Research","title":{"value":"MGI Research"},"relatedlinks":{"url":"/mgi/overview"},"landinglinks":{"jsonValue":{"value":[]}}}},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":false},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":true},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-06-20T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/mgi/our-research/investing-in-productivity-growth\"\u003eInvesting in productivity growth\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, McKinsey Global Institute, March 2024.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/mgi/our-research/investing-in-productivity-growth\"\u003eInvesting in productivity growth\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, McKinsey Global Institute, March 2024.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIncludes mainland China and Hong Kong SAR;
